awd_titl_txt: Refueling Infrastructure Preferences and the Adoption of Alternative-Fuel Vehicles
awd_abstract_narration:
This research project will examine how the geographic arrangement of alternative-fuel stations affects consumer decisions to purchase an alternative-fuel vehicle.  The project will use a number of different approaches to assess the ways in which the presence and locational arrangement of fueling and charging networks influences consumer willingness to purchase or lease alternative-fuel vehicles that operate with liquid biofuels, compressed natural gas, electricity, or hydrogen.  The project will provide new insights because it will move beyond previous studies that focused on the distance from home of a single hypothetical station or the percentage of gasoline stations that offer an alternative fuel and study how prospective adopters evaluate the geographic arrangement of a station network.  The project will consider the different dynamics of different kinds of fuel systems, moving beyond previous emphasis on slow-charging electric vehicles by giving greater attention to the more rapid recharging of newer electric vehicles and refueling of fast-filling hydrogen or natural gas vehicles.  In addition to focusing on this specific problem, the project's spatial-analytic approaches will be adaptable for use in examining other types of facilities besides fuel stations.  The project will help address a major barrier to consumer adoption of alternative-fuel vehicles: the lack of conveniently located fuel stations.  Project findings will contribute to planning more efficient and effective station networks, thereby facilitating the use of such vehicles and enabling them to serve as a more viable complement to other modes of transportation.

The investigators will use four different approaches to explore answers to the project's overarching research question:  How do prospective buyers assess the geographic arrangement of alternative fuel stations?  They will conduct an online survey of owners of compressed natural-gas vehicles in Southern California to gather information regarding where those drivers lived, worked, and refueled at the time they purchased their vehicles.  This study will reveal whether buyers were more likely to rely on a station near home when they purchased the vehicle and whether they adapted over time by switching to a station farther from home but along frequently traveled routes.  In a second study, the investigators will ask potential fuel-cell vehicle adopters in Connecticut to provide feedback regarding how maps of different refueling station networks affect their decisions to purchase a fuel-cell vehicle, thereby helping identify which criteria may be most influential among a range of options generated by optimal station location models.  In a third study, the investigators will conduct interviews with potential customers of fuel-cell vehicles in California in order to develop an ethnographic decision-tree model of the consumer decision-making process.  In the fourth study, the investigators will engage consumers and industry stakeholders in planning a network of refueling stations using a geodesign process that enables them to use geographic information systems in hands-on workshops to develop spatial plans.  By employing four different methods in three different regions for different types of vehicles, the project will enable the investigators to approach a complex issue from various angles to produce a deeper understanding of how to arrange stations to best promote adoption of alternative-fuel vehicles.

por.por_cntn:
The overarching goal of this project was to understand how the geographic arrangement of alternative-fuel refueling stations relates to the adoption of alt-fuel vehicles by drivers. We used a wide variety of methods to study this.

  1. Revealed Preference Survey of FCV Buyers in California. We surveyed hydrogen fuel cell vehicle (FCV) owners in California about the locations of the hydrogen stations they intended to use at the time they purchased their vehicle, and how their usage of particular stations changed over time. We then analyzed these data to understand how actual buyers evaluated the early and sparse network of stations in deciding whether to purchase a vehicle (Figures 1 and 2).
  2. Stated Preference Survey of Drivers in Connecticut. We surveyed drivers in the Hartford Metropolitan Area about their hypothetical willingness to purchase an FCV after viewing hypothetical maps of a small network of stations. Unbeknownst to respondents, the maps were generated by three different optimization models, which optimized proximity to homes, proximity to traffic volumes, and placement along drivers' origin-destination routes. We then analyzed these data to understand which well-known optimization model produced station plans that would make respondents more willing to purchase vehicles.
  3. Geodesign Workshop on Hydrogen Station Location in Connecticut. We organized and facilitated a participatory geodesign mapping workshop with 17 stakeholders with the Connecticut Hydrogen Fuel Cell Coalition. Participants used the Collablocation Geodesign Tool application developed specifically for this workshop, and through a structured series of collaborative breakout groups and full group sessions, they developed a plan for supplementing two existing stations with six others to be built in two stages (Figures 3 and 4).
  4. Ethnographic Decision Model of FCV Customers in California. We interviewed 44 individuals in California who purchase an FCV and 34 who seriously considered purchasing an FCV but did not. Following two rounds of structured interviews, we constructed an ethnographic decision tree model of their shared decision-making process, including how they evaluated the adequacy of the hydrogen refueling station network (Figure 5).
  5. Content Analysis of Interviews of FCV Drivers in California. For the first round of interviews with FCV owners from the ethnographic decision model study, we also applied textual content analysis to identify major themes in drivers' decisions about being an early adopter of an FCV.
  6. Geodesign Workshop on Micro-mobility Hub Location in Tempe, AZ. In an NSF INTERN Supplement to the original grant, PhD student Oscar Lopez worked with the City of Tempe Transportation Division to further develop geodesign methods for collaboratively planning networks of transportation facilities. Three 2-hour workshops were conducted with a total of 27 stakeholders using a new application of the Collablocation tool and engagement process that was modified for neighborhood-scale planning and shorter workshop sessions (Figure 6). Final recommendations for mobility hub locations from all three sessions were then analyzed and combined as recommendations to the City.

The intellectual merit of this study stems from four main innovative contributions. First and foremost, previous research on alt-fuel infrastructure planning has often prioritized a single geographic criterion - often proximity to home - when recommending where to locate stations to appeal to prospective adopters.  Through the use of mixed research methods, our results confirm that while proximity to home is indeed important, it is neither necessary nor sufficient to encourage people to adopt an AFV. It is critical to plan the refueling infrastructure as a geographic arrangement of multiple stations that satisfy multiple geographic criteria, and to keep in mind that one driver's primary neighborhood station is another driver's secondary station near work, near other destinations, or on the way to other places.

Additional theoretical and methodological intellectual merit relates to our innovative application of collaborative geodesign. Geodesign was originally developed for areal land-use planning; this study has adapted geodesign for planning a network of point facilities such as hydrogen stations and micro-mobility hubs at different spatial scales. Our research also introduced ethnographic decision tree modeling to AFV adoption and demonstrated how this method is capable of illuminating the more complex reality of how drivers evaluate the geographic network of stations, such as substituting a station near work or on the way for a primary or backup station near home.

The broader impact of this project results from better location of refueling infrastructure based on better understanding of how drivers decide whether to adopt of alt-fuel, lower-emission vehicles.  Transportation has been the most difficult sector to decarbonize. In the US, it is now the leading source of carbon dioxide emissions, having surpassed electricity generation. Gasoline and diesel vehicles are also the major source of most urban air pollution. Lack of, or inconvenient location of, refueling station infrastructure is widely acknowledged as the greatest barrier to adoption. Ultimately, our work is motivated by promoting faster and wider adoption of cleaner vehicles.
